solution_line_template: If in one hour he covers {speed} miles and rides for {distance_segment1} miles at the rate of {speed} miles per hour, then the time taken for the {distance_segment1} miles will be {distance_segment1}/{speed} = <<{distance_segment1}/{speed}={time_segment1_hours}>>{time_segment1_hours} hours.
The time in minutes is {time_segment1_hours} * {minutes_per_hour} = <<{time_segment1_hours}*{minutes_per_hour}={time_segment1_minutes}>>{time_segment1_minutes} minutes.

The time taken for the remaining {distance_segment2} miles at a rate of {speed} miles per hour is {distance_segment2}/{speed}= <<{distance_segment2}/{speed}={time_segment2_hours}>>{time_segment2_hours} hours.
The time in minutes is {time_segment2_hours}*{minutes_per_hour} = <<{time_segment2_hours}*{minutes_per_hour}={time_segment2_minutes}>>{time_segment2_minutes} minutes.

The total time taken for the whole journey is the first {initial_ride_time_minutes} minutes + {time_segment1_minutes} + {rest_time_minutes} minutes for resting +{time_segment2_minutes} minutes = <<{initial_ride_time_minutes}+{time_segment1_minutes}+{rest_time_minutes}+{time_segment2_minutes}={total_journey_time_minutes}>>{total_journey_time_minutes} minutes.
